header.p: Avoiding common styling problems is simple. And you only need efficient CSS. Nothing more.
ECSS sets simple rules for simple styling. No more naming everything, no more technological dependencies. Only intentional, consistent, simple, expressive, predictable, sustainable CSS.

section.p: üëÆ Gently nudge you and your team into ECSS.
üèÅ A quick & efficient starting point is within reach!
üì∞ Dive into ECSS principles and documentation.
Well, keep scrolling!

Because CSS as a language is misunderstood and undeservedly maligned. Because simple rules and low impact tools can go a long way in making sure the CSS codebase is light, simple and scalable. ECSS is a global approach to producing efficient design systems with CSS.

Every parcel of CSS has an objective. This objective should be clear to anyone reading the code. Be it HTML or CSS. Selectors are the perfect vehicle for intentionality. ECSS incentivizes the use of rational selectors.

Flexible naming guidelines give the codebase a consistency encouraging standardization and reuse. Prefixes and usage guidelines enforced through linting insures everyone on your team will follow ECSS rules.

p.strong: ‚ÄúSimple‚Äù is writing less code & and limiting dependencies.

section.p: Class soup & divitis aren‚Äôt simple. Untold numbers of media queries aren‚Äôt either. But modern CSS is. By accepting CSS for what it is (a designing language!) you can do a lot of styling mileage with very little code.

p.strong: Code that speaks for itself is actually achievable.

section.p: ‚Äúthumbnail as-circle with-border‚Äù is instantly understandable while ‚Äúh-10 w-10 bdr-50 br-1 overh‚Äù is not. Code should communicate information. The clearer the information, the easier it is to understand the system. Mistaken semantics should give way to expressiveness. Expressive best practices work.

p.strong: Using simple but consistent authoring rules leads to predictability.

section.p: It feels good to dive into unknown code‚Ä¶ while already knowing what it looks like. Consistency, repeating patterns, simplicity (yes, again) all coalesce into predictable code. And predictable code means less stress, less friction and happier teams!

In practice it means being at the forefront of progress and evolution. No need to wait for third parties to implement new features. You can use clamp() as of now and say goodbye to 80% of your media queries. No more sm-this md-that. Only clean and modern code.

article.h3: CSS is a designing language, not a programming one.
article.p: CSS authoring should reflect design patterns, concepts and perspectives. With global (sorry) scales, tokens, rules, etc. you limit repetition and facilitate future styling extension.

article.h3: Empowering designers to refine their work autonomously is efficient.
article.p: Making the needed parts of CSS being intelligible (code-savvy or not!) to designers cuts stress, time and promotes good allocation of human resources, refining design in the browser is a great vector of economic profitability.

article.h3: Not all CSS properties are born equal.
article.p: The box-model properties (display, position, width, etc.) are extremely sensitive and potentially way more disruptive than, say, color or type ones. The former are the stuff of professional CSS authors and the latter are the ones designers should be able to use, modify and experiment with in context.

article.h3: Properties & units have specific roles and usage.
article.p: Limiting their use to these roles enhances clarity and promotes consistency as well as predictability. The same goes for units. Some suggest type, others, images or rhythm. Use them intentionally & rationally to communicate meaning.

article.h3: Components and patterns need structure.
article.p: Trying to abstract it away is vain. Instead, documentation and dilligence are key. HTML is semantically rich, so choose the right tags and refrain from changing them for superficial reasons. One would not remove or change class="header" without understanding its purpose first, then one should not change or remove <header></header> on a whim either.

article.h3: CSS Selectors are vehicles for intention.
article.p: Every selector particle must have a purpose and if not, must be discarded with. This extraneous div in .card div h2 is what makes CSS brittle. These are not ‚Äúbest practices‚Äù.

article.h3: Selector types all have a function.
article.p: Each one of them may be of use in a certain context. No absolute usage rule should be edicted. It‚Äôs not ‚Äúalways‚Äù or ‚Äúnever‚Äù but ‚Äúit depends‚Äù and ‚Äúwhy‚Äù. Absolute rules absolutely corrupt. Or something like that.

article.h3: Selection specificity should be harnessed, not rejected.
article.p: Nevertheless, ‚Äúalways‚Äù (ahem) keep it as low as possible. Yes, in 2015 it may have not been easy. But it‚Äôs 2023 and new features are now widely supported. Use them.

article.h3: Global scope in CSS is not a sin.
article.p: Remember, CSS is a designing language and the global scope fits perfectly in design‚Äôs fundamentally layered, dimensional approach. Programming best practices are not necessarily designing best practices. Embrace design best practices.

article.h3: Global design rules must be largely anonymous & unqualified.
article.p: Only a few declarations per ruleset only. We are talking rhythm, typography, color; not display or position. This is the way of limiting repetition, bloat & complexity.

article.h3: One should wait until a concept is clearly understood before naming it.
article.p: Until then use HTML elements. Premature abstraction or ‚Äúsolving problems not yet encountered‚Äù are bigger problems than the use of header in CSS. Yes, these are programming best practices. But who told you CSS development was pure?

article.h3: When more than 3 rules are repeated more than 3 times, a concept is emerging.
article.p: Rules should then be concentrated by naming and using said concept instead of the bare rules. Reusability, expressivity and simplicity are then greatly improved.

article.h3: Named concepts must be autonomous and self-sufficient.
article.p: Named concepts should not be defined inside another named concept. If it ever is necessary, the child concept must be scoped to the parent concept and is not to be reused anywhere else.

article.h3: Manipulating named concepts throughout multiple files is strictly prohibited.
article.p: All rules for a named concept must reside in the same, unique CSS file. For authors and maintainers to have confidence in the system, there must a single source of truth for any concept.

article.h3: State, variant or structural are child concepts and must be namespaced & prefixed.
article.p: These concepts may be represented as child or combined classes. Never to be used alone, always alongside the parent concept. Yes, here are both ‚Äúnever‚Äù and ‚Äúalways‚Äù in the same sentence. ‚ÄúDouble jeopardy, we are fine‚Äù.

article.h3: Namespaced classes should generally be implemented with specificity reducing selectors.
article.p: Unless otherwise needed, one should strive to keep specificity at 21 or below. With a preference for around 10 to 12. Modern and widely supported pseudo-selectors must here be used.

article.h3: One may not come up at first with the efficient way to select interface elements.
article.p: One‚Äôs intention may not be clear at the beginning of a styling job. Instead of fruitlessly trying and trying, a code ‚Äúquarantine‚Äù file should be temporarily used until the right selection manifests itself. Still, no quarantine file should ever be published publicly.

article.h3: HTML should be as simple and expressive as can be.
article.p: Refrain from over-containing, don‚Äôt use <div> where you could use <aside>. Dont wrap your single-level navigation in unordered lists. And yes, simple navigation is accessible. Keep it simple‚Ä¶ Suzy.

article.h3: Any HTML element should endorse one role only.
article.p: As per the famous programming best practice (again, programming in designing), semantic tags are for‚Ä¶ semantics whilst <div> or <span> tags are for graphical or logical division. Any type of grid should be implemented with <div> tags.

article.h3: Any media query adaptation must be included in its related concept‚Äôs file.
article.p: Not as as a separate file, not as suffixed classes. If one uses utility classes, the provided rules should not be query dependent but rather be universally needed, in every media configuration.

article.h3: Whole stylesheets are better used when global.
article.p: Media query scopes should be used in HTML <link> tags to promote reuse, performance and optimization concerns. Each fundamental design layer should be autonomous, independent and removable.

article.h3: Component styling should only be served with live components.
article.p: Not as a big minified file in the <head> tag of the document. This way, the infamous problem of loading unused CSS is practically solved, without any technological debt. First render is also faster since only what is used is processed by the browser. As a bonus, you get the CSS file path in component file.

article.h3: Let the browser do as much of the rendering work as it can.
article.p: By embracing fluidity, adaptativity is mostly done by the browser. Less rules are needed to insure correct rendering in the infinite number of usage contexts.

article.h3: Make full use of freely available development tools by going with the grain of the Web platform.
article.p: By using ‚Äújust-in-time‚Äù rulesets, design tokens, the cascade and intentional selection, the debugging & refining workflow is simpler, lighter and clearer.

article.h3: Eschewing technological abstractions like high-level frameworks spurs lighter, simpler native code.
article.p: By writing native CSS, one uses CSS better; by writing native HTML, one writes HTML better. With better CSS and better HTML comes a better user experience.

header.h3: All component selectors must start with its filename.

section.p: To exclude a file from this rule in the Stylelint config, prefix the filename with a digit or ‚Äúx-‚Äù as in ‚Äúx-quarantine.css‚Äù

header.h3: All paddings should first be uniform and then be adjusted if necessary.

section.p: Non-uniform paddings may be used in particular instances for overflow reasons or for added pseudo-content.

header.h3: Paddings are to be applied on containing and interactive elements only.

section.p: Text elements should only host text styles while container elements can host theming styles. In some instances, container elements could host text styles to be inherited by children.

header.h3: Horizontal margins should not be applied to text elements.

section.p: Horizontal margins can be applied to text elements in the case of inline elements such as icons or tags & on indented elements like blockquote.

header.h3: Typographic elements should use heritage when possible.
Design tokens should be used for most numerical values.

section.p: Numerical values should only be used for exceptional alignments. These should be commented to communicate the intent. Even then, why not create a bespoke property meaningfully named?

header.h3: Repeating default rules is discouraged.

section.p: Any instance of repeating default must be justified in a comment.

header.h3: All class entities besides components must be prefixed.
Nesting is restricted to one level only.
The use of specific dimensions should be avoided.
Use attribute selectors to convey unicity.
The use of positioning and display rules should minimized.

section.p: Use these properties only on elements needing them. Use the narrowest selectors that makes sense in the context.

header.h3: Overqualified selectors are discouraged.
Components cannot exert outside influence.
Overflow should not be hidden.

section.p: By hiding the way browsers treat overflowing items, we may hide content without knowing. By using auto instead of hidden, the oveflowing content will be accessible and the scrollbar will signal the design problem instead of hiding it. Hiding scrollbars may be necessary in some particular composition (see this very site‚Äôs portrait adaptation for an example!).

header.h3: Numbers in class names are to be avoided.

section.p: Numbers may convey intention in grid system cases as in, for example, grid-10 or col-3. Still, the utility of these systems is low in modern CSS times. Leaving them aside is suggested.

header.h3: Magic numbers must be avoided or explained in a line comment.

section.p: Value and unit choices should be dictated by the graphic language and its design tokens. Absolute values in numerical form should be reserved to special cases like bespoke icon alignment or bullet list padding. The intention must be clear in itself or commented if not.

header.h3: Rhythm must be applied in one direction only, preferably top.

section.p: Spacing is rhythm, a fundamental design concept. Rhythm occurs between graphical elements and should be applied as such in CSS. The lobotomized owl selector (+) is tailor made for this task. When using a flex container, the gap property does it all for you!

header.h3: The use of problematic units is discouraged.

section.p: Static viewport units (vh, vw, vmin, vmax) are famously problematic, particularly when used as 100vh or 100vw. Dynamic viewport units are better suited for this task.

header.h3: Tag selectors should be leveraged inside components.
One entity per file with a soft cap of about a hundred lines.

section.p: This is one of the most important rules for achieving sustainable CSS. One autonomous concept per file prevents the multiplication of overrides and redefinition across the codebase.

header.h3: Selectors must strictly include only necessary selection parts.

section.p: This mistake, being passed as ‚Äúbest practices‚Äù, is the source of many self-induced CSS headaches. Fortunately, the solution is simple: do not use selection parts that you could remove without changing the original intention.

header.h3: Duplication of a set of more than 3 rules is discouraged.
The use of the global scope is encouraged for all fundamental design layers.
HTML structure should be as flat as possible and bereft of single tag nesting.

section.p: Sometimes it could make sense to add a div even if it‚Äôs the only child. The case of a content grid comes to mind. See this page‚Äôs source for an example.

header.h3: Specificity must be kept as low as possible.

section.p: Sometimes it makes sense to add specificity. But don‚Äôt do it until proven necessary.
